Todd Beiger <tbeiger@coca-cola.com>    Subject: Fwd: INFORM: CCNA refranchising coverage    FYI    Sent from my iPhone    Begin forwarded message:    From: Scott Leith <sleith.^Goxa::.ccilaaGmri>    Date: April 20, 2016 at 5:00:32 PM EDT    To: Scott Williamson <,sw.iiliani^    Subject: INFORM: CCNA refranchising coverage    CCNA's refranchising announcement was picked up by numerous outlets, including mentions in stories about earnings overall. Many of the stories focused on Junior Bridgeman, a successful restaurant franchise owner and former NBA player who is joining the Coca-Cola system. Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution, Coca-Cola Beverages Florida and Swire Coca-Cola, USA also sent out local press releases. Here are some of the highlights from the coverage:    Junior Bridgeman trades restaurants for Coca-Cola Major Wendy's, Chili's franchisee to become a Coca-Cola bottler    Nation's Restaurant News    By Jonathan Maze    http://nrn.CQm/franchisinq/juniQr-bridqeman-trades-restaurants-    Junior Bridgeman is trading his Frosty for a Coke.    The former NBA player who became an even greater success as a Wendy's and Chili's franchisee is selling his restaurant interests after reaching a deal to become a bottler for The  pgNbr=1 Coca-Cola Company, the Atlanta-based soft-drink producer said Wednesday.    According to the release, Bridgeman is in the process of divesting his restaurant holdings, which include about 240 Wendy's locations and 120 Chili's units in 16 states. Bridgeman's restaurant company is based in Louisville, Ky. His bottling operation will also be located there.    The deal would continue a major shift in the ownership of Wendy's locations in particular. Bridgeman would be the second longtime, large-scale operator to sell his locations this year. Earlier this year, Dick Fox, an operator of 113 locations, sold restaurants to three different operators.    In addition, Wendy's continues to refranchise company-owned locations.    Bridgeman played for 12 years in the NBA, mostly with the Milwaukee Bucks. He purchased his first three Wendy's restaurants while still playing basketball, and built on those holdings after he retired in 1987.    Bridgeman, through his company Manna Inc., signed a deal to acquire bottling territory from Atlanta-based Coca-Cola in Missouri, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska. He will also acquire a production facility in Lenexa, Kan. Manna Inc. will become only the third new independent Coca-Cola bottler in recent decades, the company said.    ###    Bridgeman firm joining Coca-Cola network    Louisville Courier-Journal By Sheldon S. Shafer http://www.courier-j.Q.uinaLGQ.m^ firmjQirjin^^^^    The Coca-Cola Co. system has a new bottler, a company named Manna Inc. founded by former University of Louisville and professional basketball star and restaurant magnate Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman.    The news announced by the soft drink company Wednesday comes amid its continued progress in refranchising its North American bottling operations.  pgNbr=2 Bridgeman retired from the National Basketball Association in 1987 and has developed a business portfolio that has made him one of the largest restaurant franchise operators in the country.    Bridgeman is in the process of divesting his restaurant holdings, which include dozens of Wendy's and Chili's franchises, to focus on his future business in the Coca-Cola system, according to a news release from Coca-Cola.    In Louisville, Bridgeman also has a stake in the Mark's Feed Store outlets, Napa River Grill and the new BirraCibo restaurant at 4th Street Live.    Bridgeman has signed a letter of intent to acquire territory from Coca-Cola in Missouri, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska, including the cities of St. Louis and Kansas City, the release said.    Bridgeman will also acquire a production facility in Lenexa, Kan. Justin Bridgeman, one of his sons, will lead the company with his father.    The new bottling company will become the third new, independent Coca-Cola bottler in recent decades. The others are Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution LLC and Coca-Cola Beverages Florida LLC.    Coca-Cola of Northern New England, which has been part of the Coca-Cola system since 1977, has signed a letter of intent to take on additional territory from the Coca-Cola Company.    ###    Junior Bridgeman shedding restaurants; signs major deal with Coca-Cola    Louisville Business First By David A. Mann    http://www.bizJQurnals.CQm/lQuisville/news/2Q18/Q4/2Q/juniQr-    Restaurant industry veteran and former basketball great Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman is getting out of the Wendy's business and becoming a Coca-Cola bottler.    The Coca-Cola Co. (NYSE: KO) announced the move today, saying it coincides with its re-franchising of its North American bottling operations.  pgNbr=3 Bridgeman's company, Manna Inc., is the Coca-Cola system's newest bottler, the release said. Bridgeman is a former University of Louisville and Milwaukee Bucks player who established his business interests by purchasing three Wendy's franchises while he was still playing basketball, according to the news release.    Bridgeman retired from the NBA in 1987 and expanded his portfolio of businesses to become one of the largest restaurant franchise operators in the country. He also is one of the highest paid former athletes in the country.    The release says Bridgeman is in the process of divesting his restaurant holdings, which include Wendy's and Chili's franchises, to focus on his future business in the Coca-Cola system.    It's not clear whether that includes some of his smaller restaurant interests, such as the Mark's Feed Store chain, BirraCibo on Fourth Street and Napa River Grill in Westport Village. There also is no indication of who might buy the restaurant operations. I called Bridgeman today, but I haven't heard back.    Bridgeman has signed a letter of intent to acquire territory from The Coca-Cola Co. (NYSE: KO) in Missouri, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska, including St. Louis and Kansas City. Bridgeman also will acquire a production facility in Lenexa, Kan.    Justin Bridgeman, one of Junior Bridgeman's sons, will lead the company with his father.    The new bottling company will be only the third new, independent Coca-Cola bottler in recent decades, the release said. The others are Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution LLC and Coca-Cola Beverages Florida LLC.    ###    Junior Bridgeman selling restaurant franchises to become Coca-Cola distributor    Milwaukee Business Journal By David Schuyler    http://media.bizj.us/view/img/8038722/dave-schuyler-3x4-    Former Milwaukee Bucks great and Louisville, Ky.,  pgNbr=4 businessman Junior Bridgeman is getting out of the restaurant business � which includes Wendy's and Chili's franchises in Wisconsin � to become a distributor for The Coca-Cola Co.    Atlanta-based Coca-Cola (NYSE: KO) announced Bridgeman's plans in a press release Wednesday that also announced the planned sale of the Coca-Cola bottling facility on Brown Deer Road in Milwaukee to a distributor based in Rosemont, III. The deal comes two-and-a-half years after Coca-Cola announced a $30 million expansion of the facility. Terms of sale were not disclosed.    With the new distribution deal, Bridgeman will become just the third new independent Coca-Cola bottler in recent decades, Coca-Cola said. Under Bridgeman's letter of intent with the beverage company, he will acquire territory from Coca-Cola Co. in Missouri, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska, including the cities of St. Louis and Kansas City.    Bridgeman also will acquire a production facility in Lenexa, Kan. He will lead the company along with his son, Justin Bridgeman.    Junior Bridgeman played 12 NBA seasons from 1975 to 1987, including 10 with the Bucks. After retiring, Bridgeman bought five Milwaukee-area Wendy's franchises, and his portfolio added Chili's franchises and has more than 450 restaurants, Forbes estimated in ranking him fourth on its recent list of highest-paid retired athletes.    Coca-Cola Co., based in Atlanta, has been refranchising its North American bottling operations. In addition to the deal with Bridgeman, the company announced expanded territories for three other bottlers, including independent bottler Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution LLC of Rosemont, which is buying the Milwaukee plant.    ###    Coca-Cola plants in Niles, Alsip to be acquired by Reyes Holdings    Chicago Tribune By Greg Trotter    http://www.chicagotribune.CQm/business/ct-CQca-CQla-plants-acqyjre�d.:D42l.:M    Reyes Holdings announced Wednesday plans to acquire Coca-Cola plants in Niles and Alsip, along with four other  pgNbr=5 facilities in the Midwest.    Rosemont-based Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution, a subsidiary of Reyes Holdings, has signed a letter of intent to buy the plants from the Coca-Cola Co. and take over production. The other facilities are in Milwaukee; Detroit; Grand Rapids, Mich.; and Eagan, Minn. Terms of the deal, expected to close by the end of 2017, weren't disclosed.    When asked if the deal would result in layoffs, Meredith Simpson, a Reyes Holdings spokeswoman, said the company doesn't "expect that there will be any changes to the workforce."    In January, members of Teamsters Local 727 voted to approve a three-year contract with Coca-Cola, ending contentious negotiations that included a strike that lasted nearly a month. The contract covers 319 production and warehouse workers and transport drivers at the two Illinois plants.    ###    Reyes to buy 6 Coca-Cola production plants    Chicago Sun-Times By Bill Ruminski    http://chicago.suntlmes.com/news/reyes-to-buy-6-coca-cola-production-plants/    Food and beverage distributor Reyes Holdings said Wednesday it intends to buy six production plants from The Coca-Cola Co., including ones in Alsip and Niles.    The deal will be the first foray into bottling by Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution LLC, which is owned by Rosemont-based Reyes Holdings. The other plants are in Detroit and Grand Rapids, Michigan.; Eagan, Minnesota; and Milwaukee.    "The agreement allows Reyes Holdings and our family of businesses not only to grow our partnership with Coca-Cola, but also to become a producing bottler for the first time," Chris Reyes, founder and co-chairman of Reyes Holdings, said in a news release.    Great Lakes Coca-Cola said it expects to complete the purchase in stages by the end of 2017. Financial terms weren't released.    The company acquired the Chicago-area distribution rights for  pgNbr=6 Coca-Cola in 2014 and last fall announced an expansion that eventually will include Michigan, most of Wisconsin, and parts of southern Minnesota, northeast Iowa and northern Illinois.    Reyes Holdings's beverage group is a large beer distributor, working with MillerCoors as well as many craft beers.    ###    Coca-Cola selling Michigan locations to a Chicago distributor    Mlive/Grand Rapids Press By Shandra Martinez    hiip://www^    michigan/index.ssf/2Q16/Q4/coca-    CHICAGO - Two Michigan Coca-Cola distribution centers in Detroit and Grand Rapids will soon have a new owner.    The two locations are among six Midwest production facilities the Coca-Cola Company has signed a letter of intent to sell to the Chicago-area Coca-Cola distributor, Great Lakes Coca-Cola Distribution.    The Michigan locations are at 12225 Oakland Pkwy, Highland Park, in Detroit and at 1440 Butterworth Drive SW, in Grand Rapids,.    The Coca-Cola plant has been located on Grand Rapids' Southwest Side since 1949. The 138,000-square-foot facility underwent a nearly $34 million expansion in 2000, that added a 168,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution center. At the time, the plant employed about a 100 people, according to a Grand Rapids Press story.    The other product facilities are located in Alsip and Niles, III.; Eagan, Minn.; and Milwaukee.    This move marks Rosemont, III.-headquartered Great Lakes' entry into production in the Midwest and further strengthens its partnership with Coca-Cola, the firm said in a statement released Wednesday by Reyes Holdings, owner of Great Lakes.    "The agreement allows Reyes Holdings and our family of businesses not only to grow our partnership with Coca-Cola, but also to become a producing bottler for the first time," Chris  pgNbr=7 Reyes, founder and co-chairman of Reyes Holdings, said in a statement.    The sale of the bottling plants are part of Coca-Cola North America's goal to refranchise its North American bottling operations by 2017.    So far, the beverage giant has reached definitive agreements or signed letters of intent to refranchise territories that account for about half of its bottler-delivered distribution volume in the United States, the company said.    "We continue to make great progress in refranchising, and these agreements show that our partners are strongly interested in expanding," J. Alexander "Sandy" Douglas Jr., president of Coca-Cola North America, said in a statement. "These bottlers are investing in the future of the Coca-Cola system. We are also pleased to welcome a new bottler to the Coca-Cola family."    Great Lakes previously announced the expansion of its distribution territory across the Midwest in October.    With the closing of those transactions in 2016 and 2017, Great Lakes will have exclusive rights for the sales and distribution of Coca-Cola beverages in Michigan, the majority of Wisconsin, the greater Minneapolis - St. Paul region and portions of northeast Iowa and northern Illinois adjacent to its Chicago territory.    Reyes Holdings is the 12th largest privately-held U.S. company with more than 18,000 employees and annual sales of $24 billion. The company delivers more than 900 million cases of beverage and food products from 142 warehouses in North, Central and South America, as well as Europe, the Middle East and Asia Pacific.    ###    Hartford Coca-Cola production facility sold    Hartford Business Journal    By Keith Griffin    http://www.harttbrdbusiness.com/aiticle/2016Q420/NEWS01/160^^    Coca-Cola, as part of ongoing strategy to divest itself of company-owned bottling operations across the country, is selling its Hartford production outpost and other New England facilities to a New Hampshire bottler.  pgNbr=8 No financial details of the transaction were released.    New Hampshire's Coca-Cola of Northern New England, which is a franchisee of Coca-Cola, has signed a letter of intent to operate Coke production facilities in several major cities, including Boston, Providence, R.I., and Hartford.    Nationwide, Coca-Cola has reached definitive agreements or signed letters of intent to refranchise production plants that account for approximately 50 percent of bottler-delivered distribution volume in the United States.    ###    New deal pops for Coca-Cola Beverages Florida    Tampa Bay Business Journal    By Margie Manning    http ://w ww .bizj ournals. com/tampab ay /news/2016/04/20/new- deal -    A Tampa Coca-Cola bottler is going to start making the beverages it already sells.    Coca-Cola Beverages Florida has signed a letter of intent with The Coca-Cola Co. (NYSE: KO) to acquire four production facilities in Tampa, Orlando, Jacksonville and Hollywood.    Financial terms were not disclosed in a press release announcing the planned purchase by Coca-Cola Florida, which is already one of the largest private companies and a major employer in the area.    The deal allows Coca-Cola Florida, which markets, sells and distributes Coca-Cola products in central Florida, to deepen its roots in the Sunshine State, Troy Taylor, chairman and CEO, said in the release.    "These acquisitions will enable us to not only own, but to optimize the process of refreshing Floridians, from production to a cold beverage in hand," he said.    The new deal comes on the heels of pending acquisitions of Coca-Cola Co.'s sales and distribution operations in North Florida and in South Florida. The North Florida deal is expected to close this year, with the South Florida operations scheduled for close next year, subject to both sides reaching a definitive agreement.  pgNbr=9 Coca-Cola Florida, organized in early 2014, already is one of the largest independently owned and operated Coca-Cola bottlers in the United States, and had more than $350 million in annual revenue and 1,100 employees, about half of them at the company's headquarters in the Brandon area, Taylor told Tampa Bay Business Journal in an interview last year.    Coca-Cola Co., headquartered in Atlanta, has been refranchising its North American bottling operations. In addition to the deal with Coca-Cola Florida, the company announced a new independent bottler in the Midwest and expanded territories for three other bottlers.    Sales at Coca-Cola Co. fell for the fourth consecutive quarter, Fortune reported, citing a drop in demand as consumers focus on beverages that are viewed as healthy, as well as a strong dollar that's eroding the value of sales outside the United States.    ###    Coke Profit and Revenue Fall as Volume Is Flat    The Wall Street Journal By Anne Steele    http://www.wsj.com/articles/coke-profit-and-revenue-fall-on-flat-volurne-1481152837    Coca-Cola Co. on Wednesday said revenue and profit declined in its latest quarter as soda volume was flat amid weakness abroad.    Shares, up 13% over the past three months, fell 1.8% premarket to $45.77, although results edged in just above Wall Street's expectations.    Coke has been struggling with weakness overseas, with key countries such as Russia and Brazil in recession, consumer demand weak in Europe and Japan, and China's economy slowing. Weakening foreign currencies also are hitting Coke, which generates about half its sales abroad but translates results into dollars.    The company has been able to offset that in part by raising prices and steering consumers to smaller packages that cost more per ounce in its U.S. market.    For the first quarter, Coke reported that its beverage volumes grew 2% both world-wide and in its key North American  pgNbr=10 market.    Chief Executive Muhtar Kent said amid a "challenging global macro environment," the company delivered "positive top-line growth and strong underlying margin expansion."    "We are confident that we have the right strategies in place to achieve our full-year outlook," he said.    Noncarbonated drinks, which include tea, packaged water and sports drinks, continued to log strong growth at 7%, driven by solid volume across all key categories except for juice and juice drinks which declined slightly. Soda volumes were even in the quarter globally, and in North America, where growth in Sprite, Fanta and energy drinks was offset by a decline in the namesake Coca-Cola brand.    Overall, Coke posted a profit of $1.48 billion, or 34 cents a share, down from $1.56 billion, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier.    Excluding certain items, per-share earnings were 45 cents, edging in above the 44 cents analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast.    The company said foreign exchange shaved 12 percentage points off its per-share earnings in the quarter.    Revenue fell 4% to $10.28 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast revenue of $10.27 billion. The top line was hurt by one less day compared with the prior-year period.    Also Wednesday, Coke, which has been accelerating the restructuring of its North American operations, outlined more changes to its bottling network.    Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman, a former NBA player and founder of Manna Inc., signed a letter of intent to buy territory from Coke in Missouri, Illinois, Kansas and Nebraska. He will also acquire a production facility in Lenexa, Kan. Bedford, N.H.-based Coca-Cola of Northern New England will take on additional territory from the company throughout New England, acquiring production facilities in Needham Heights, Mass., and Hartford.    The company also said bottlers in Mississippi and Colorado would expand their operations and bottlers in Florida and Chicago would acquire a total of 10 production facilities. Coke  pgNbr=11 also said it plans to grant additional territory rights in Albuquerque, N.M., to Swire Coca-Cola USA.    ###    Just 3rd New Coke Bottler in Decades Being Created --Market Talk    Dow Jones    By Kevin Kingsbury    Ahead of its 1Q report, Coke (KO) said just the 3rd independent bottler "in recent decades" will be created as it reaches a deal with former NBA 6th man "Junior" Bridgeman, who has gone on to have a reported $400M net worth through becoming a big Wendy's (WEN) franchisee. He is buying bottling territory from KO in 4 midwestern states and a Kansas production facility while selling his restaurant holdings, which include locations of Brinker (EAT)-owned Chili's. KO, which also announces 3 other refranchising deals with current bottlers, comes as the company has been reversing a prior effort to also own its bottling operations.    ###    Coca-Cola Underwhelms Investors Seeking Faster Turnaround    Bloomberg    By Jennifer Kaplan    http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-20/coca-    CQla-prQfit-tQps-estimates-as-new-drink-sizes-bQQSt-sales    Coca-Cola Co. posted first-quarter results that mostly met analysts' expectations, underwhelming investors who'd been optimistic that a stronger turnaround was taking hold.    Earnings were 45 cents a share, excluding some items, the Atlanta-based company said in a statement on Wednesday. Analysts estimated 44 cents, on average. Sales fell 4 percent to $10.3 billion, matching analysts' average projection.    The results show Coca-Cola's strategy of cost cuts and price increases is paying off, just not fast enough for some investors' liking. While Chief Executive Officer Muhtar Kent has made progress by revamping the company's bottling system and starting a $3 billion productivity program, the maker of Diet Coke and Fanta is continuing to struggle with health-conscious consumers' shift away from drinking soda.  pgNbr=12 "The penny beat on the bottom line is perhaps not as encouraging as one might expect, because you've got some softness on the top line," said Vivien Azer, an analyst at Cowen & Co. "We view soda as the new cigarette, which would result in that category, and Coke in particular, realizing structural volume declines from here on out."    Sales volume for Coca-Cola's sparkling beverages was little changed in the quarter, while noncarbonated beverages gained 7 percent.    Shares of Coca-Cola fell as much as 4.9 percent to $44.30 in New York trading, the biggest intraday decline since August. The stock was up 8.5 percent this year through Tuesday, beating the 2.8 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.    Currency Effects    Coca-Cola is facing currency headwinds abroad and declining soda consumption at home. To combat those trends, the company has introduced smaller bottles and cans that cost more per ounce of liquid than traditional cans and bottles. The efforts have helped somewhat. Coca-Cola's operating margin, excluding currency effects and other items, expanded to 24.8 percent from 23.4 percent. Still, net income fell 4.8 percent to $1.48 billion, or 34 cents a share.    In a bid to improve earnings, Kent has been divesting asset-heavy bottling operations, which lets Coca-Cola focus on the more profitable business of selling concentrates and syrups to the companies that manufacture, package and distribute the drinks. Coca-Cola announced more progress on that front Wednesday, saying it is selling territory to three existing bottlers and one newly formed bottler, led by former National Basketball Association player Ulysses "Junior" Bridgeman. To date, the beverage giant has transferred or signed agreements for about two-thirds of company-owned bottling systems.    Coca-Cola, which makes Simply juices and Honest Tea, also is putting a greater focus on noncarbonated drinks. And just ahead of earnings, the company announced a new marketing initiative that will combine all of its namesake sodas into one brand. Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke, Coke Zero and Coke Life will be part of the campaign, which will start in Mexico.    "Things are truly getting better at Coke, and the underlying improvement in fundamentals has created a positive marginal  pgNbr=13 change story, which we think is why the stock has outperformed," John Faucher, an analyst at JPMorgan Chase & Co., wrote in a note before the results were released. "That said, with valuation moving higher and earnings likely flat to down until the back half of 2017 as a result of the bottler refranchising, we see limited room for further upside from here."  pgNbr=14

This document also includes some information about US beverage tax  pgNbr=1 trends and addresses many of the misperceptions people have about these taxes.    Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions for this document. We will continue to update it as the situation in Philadelphia develops.    Thanks, Ben      pgNbr=2 Philadelphia Beverage Tax Background and TCCC Position    Beverage Tax Background:    Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney introduced a 3-cent per ounce tax on beverages with sugar. The tax was positioned as a critical need in order to pay for universal Pre-K and other investments in schools and parks and recreation. Some media and industry critics argue this tax reflects a "tipping point" within our culture and the nation regarding soft drinks. However, the facts and history of beverage taxes show a different picture. Despite rejecting a tax on beverages with sugar twice in the last eight years, Philadelphia's City Council has advanced a proposal to tax beverages with sugar and "artificially sweetened drinks" at 1.5 cents per ounce. The Council is expected to approve the tax and the Mayor will sign it before July 1, 2016. However, the local coalition continues working to stop the tax from achieving final passage.    In the moments before the tax was approved, the administration revealed that most of the funds from the tax would not fund programs like Pre-K until three years from now. Instead, the bulk of the money will go to pay the general fund balance. Although the trend in the US in the last decade has been the rejection of beverage taxes, the recent passage of taxes in Berkeley, CA and now in Philadelphia are controversial exceptions.    TCCC's Philadelphia Tax Position:    TCCC opposes the Philadelphia tax proposal because it unfairly targets one product, disproportionately impacts low-income and elderly communities and hurts small businesses. Singling out one product category, like nonalcoholic beverages, is an unreliable way to fund important local initiatives like Pre-K education.    If collecting money is the goal, which is the case in Philadelphia, in order to collect the money and avoid altering industries, the most effective way is to broaden the base or use existing taxes. We know that governments need resources but discriminatory taxes are not the solution.    While the tax has been approved by City Council's Committee of the Whole, we will continue working with local Philadelphia restaurants, grocers, small businesses, citizens and beverage companies to oppose this regressive tax. Together with our coalition partners, we are exploring all options and will make an announcement about our next steps soon.    Background on Beverage Taxes:    There are fewer soft drink/beverage taxes in the US today than in recent history.    �  Many state beverage excise taxes (e.g. Ohio, New York, North Carolina and South Carolina) were on the books for decades, but repealed in late 1980s-1990s.    �  Only two states currently have taxes on soft drinks: Arkansas (enacted 1992) and West Virginia (enacted 1951). Both states rank among the highest in the nation for obesity.    �  Many states impose sales taxes on foods and beverages, and our Company does not oppose these types of broad-based taxes.    US cities and states have consistently rejected new tax proposals.    �  In the last eight years, 43 out of 44 different tax proposals have been rejected.    �  The only recent tax to pass was in Berkeley, CA.    �  Polling data showed 58 percent of Philadelphians oppose a tax on beverages.    �  These taxes are consistently rejected because the public opposes them. A Harris Poll found that nationally, 62 percent of Americans oppose these taxes.    Sales taxes are not "beverage taxes".    �  There's a difference between sales taxes and excise taxes. Many states apply sales taxes to all foods and beverages and is based on a percentage of what you buy. Excise taxes target one specific item and are often a flat rate owed on top of what you buy.    �  TCCC does not oppose sales taxes on our products because they are applied fairly across most other food and beverage items found in grocery stores and restaurants.  pgNbr=3 �  If collecting money is the goal, which is the case in Philadelphia, in order to collect the money and avoid altering industries, the most effective way is to broaden the base or use existing taxes. We know that governments need resources, but discriminatory taxes are not the solution.    "Big Soda" is not the only opposition to beverage taxes.    �  TCCC, its competitors, and the American Beverage Association support and organize efforts to oppose beverage taxes.    �  Local, small businesses and citizens voluntarily join our efforts to form coalitions. For example, in Philadelphia, the local coalition included 1400 businesses and 25,000 individuals.    �  Coalitions include real, local businesses and people who take action on their own - often at putting their reputation and business at risk.    �  Local coalitions do the bulk of the work to oppose taxes: send letters, make phone calls, talk to media and attend rallies - all to protect their jobs, businesses and grocery bills.    �  Local voices from grocers, retailers, restaurants, organized labor and citizens are much more effective in advocating against beverage taxes.    �  City council members and state legislators care a lot more about the impact of a tax on their local constituents than on a multinational beverage company.    Q&A:    When is the City Council expected to vote on the tax?    We expect the full council to vote on the bill June 16, 2016.    When would the tax be effective?    We expect it would be effective on January 1, 2017.    Who would pay the tax?    The tax is applied at the distributor level. As a result, customers and consumers can expect to pay higher prices for beverages.    Would the tax apply to diets?    Yes, "artificially sweetened" beverages are included.    If passed, will the tax apply to fountain?    Yes on finished product, at 1.5-cents per ounce.  pgNbr=4
